verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
verses.comment: Eliphaz, who spoke previously in Job 4, responds again. Eliphaz represents the voice of traditional wisdom, critiquing Job's answers.

verses.text: "Should a wise man answer with windy knowledge, and fill his belly with the east wind?
verses.comment: Eliphaz questions the wisdom of Job's words, comparing them with empty wind—an ancient idiom for empty talk. Note the poetic parallel in Job 8:2.

verses.text: Should he argue with words that are useless, or with speeches that do no good?
verses.comment: Eliphaz continues accusing Job of speaking without wisdom or profit, reminiscent of similar accusations elsewhere in Job.

verses.text: Yes, you even do away with reverent fear, and hinder meditation before God.
verses.comment: Eliphaz charges Job not just with folly, but undermining proper fear and worship of God. This refers to maintaining public devotion and regular prayer, a theme later echoed in New Testament piety (see Acts 2:42).

verses.text: For your iniquity teaches your mouth, and you choose the language of the crafty.
verses.comment: Eliphaz claims Job's sin has corrupted his speech, implying the heart and mouth are linked (see Matt. 12:34). A subtle spiritual interpretation is that speech reveals interior disposition, aligning with traditional teachings about words and the moral life.

verses.text: Your own mouth condemns you, not I; your own lips testify against you.
verses.comment: Eliphaz insists Job's words are self-condemning. This introduces the idea that one's own testimony stands before God, anticipating James 3:6's caution about the tongue.

verses.text: "Were you the first man born? Were you brought forth before the hills?
verses.comment: Eliphaz ironically questions Job's claim to unique knowledge. Reference to 'before the hills' echoes Wisdom's pre-existence (Prov. 8:25), which Christian tradition later applies to Christ.

verses.text: Have you listened in the council of God? Do you limit wisdom to yourself?
verses.comment: Eliphaz refers to the 'council of God,' a mysterious image of divine deliberation found also in Ps. 82. This hints at God revealing wisdom through tradition and community, not just individuals.

verses.text: What do you know that we do not know? What do you understand that is not clear to us?
verses.comment: Eliphaz stresses the shared deposit of wisdom among the wise, not individual revelation alone. Compare ancient worship's communal aspect in Deuteronomy and Psalms.

verses.text: Both the gray-haired and the aged are among us, older than your father.
verses.comment: Eliphaz invokes tradition and the wisdom of elders. This highlights the need for continuity in faith and reliance on those who came before, a perennial theme in the spiritual life.

verses.text: Are the consolations of God too little for you, or the mild word spoken to you?
verses.comment: Eliphaz refers to divine consolation, a theme found throughout Scripture and the Christian life (see 2 Cor. 1:3-4 on God as the comforter).

verses.text: Why does your heart carry you away? And why do your eyes flash,
verses.comment: Eliphaz accuses Job of being led by emotion instead of reason and tradition, which points to the tension between individual struggle and communal faith.

verses.text: so that you turn your spirit against God, and let such words come out of your mouth?
verses.comment: Eliphaz warns against rebellion against God, paralleling the temptation scenes where Job is challenged to curse God.

verses.text: "What is man, that he should be pure, or he who is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
verses.comment: The universality of human sin is underscored, echoed by Paul's teaching that all have sinned (Rom. 3:23). This prepares for New Testament teaching on grace and redemption in Christ.

verses.text: Behold, God puts no trust even in his holy ones, and the heavens are not pure in his sight;
verses.comment: A cosmic scope of sin is presented—even heavenly beings are imperfect before God's majesty. This furthers the idea that salvation requires something beyond human or even angelic effort.

verses.text: how much less one who is abominable and corrupt, a man who drinks injustice like water!
verses.comment: Eliphaz portrays humanity's brokenness in vivid terms, using the metaphor of drinking iniquity. Note also the allusion to Psalm 14's description of universal corruption.

verses.text: "I will show you; listen to me; what I have seen I will declare,
verses.comment: Eliphaz appeals to his own experience, reflecting the ancient importance of eyewitness and oral tradition in religious matters.

verses.text: what wise men have told, and have not hidden from their fathers,
verses.comment: Emphasis is on the transmission of wisdom across generations, continually taught and preserved—a theme relevant to the value of tradition in the spiritual life.

verses.text: to whom alone the land was given, and no stranger passed among them."
verses.comment: Eliphaz claims ancient wisdom arose in a people uniquely set apart, recalling the notion of God working through a chosen people and a sense of unbroken, divinely guided heritage.

verses.text: The wicked man writhes in pain all his days, through all the years that are laid up for the oppressor.
verses.comment: Eliphaz presents the suffering of the wicked as a principle, paralleling the Psalmist's struggle (Ps. 73), but lacking Job's later challenge to this simple view.

verses.text: A sound of terror is in his ears; in prosperity the destroyer comes upon him.
verses.comment: The link between internal turmoil and outward destruction is developed; the lack of lasting peace points ahead to the hope for a redeemer who brings true peace.

verses.text: He does not believe that he will return out of darkness, and he is destined for the sword.
verses.comment: The wicked are portrayed as hopeless, their fate sealed by their choices—a motif contrasted by later scriptural revelations about mercy beyond death.

verses.text: He wanders for bread, saying, 'Where is it?' He knows that a day of darkness is at hand.
verses.comment: Physical and spiritual hunger are mingled in this image, foreshadowing Gospel themes of spiritual poverty and the bread of life (John 6:35).

verses.text: Distress and anguish terrify him; they overpower him, like a king ready for battle.
verses.comment: The imagery of overwhelming judgment comes, echoing Old Testament descriptions of divine punishment and the sovereignty of God.

verses.text: Because he has stretched out his hand against God and acts defiantly toward the Almighty,
verses.comment: Defiance against God is the cardinal sin described here; a reminder of the need for humility and submission in the spiritual life.

verses.text: running stubbornly at him with a thick, strong shield,
verses.comment: A military image underlines the futility of contending with God. This theme is picked up in Paul's reflections on spiritual warfare and the weakness of the flesh (Rom. 8:7).

verses.text: because he has covered his face with his fat and gathered fat upon his waist,
verses.comment: The imagery of pride and self-indulgence conveys spiritual sluggishness, often contrasted with the call to self-discipline found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: he has lived in desolate cities, in houses which no one should inhabit, which were destined to become heaps of ruins.
verses.comment: Eliphaz connects pride and judgment with desolation—a frequent prophetic symbol for divine displeasure.

verses.text: He will not become rich, his wealth will not endure, nor will his possessions spread over the earth.
verses.comment: Earthly riches are transient; spiritual interpretation emphasizes real treasure is in heaven (see Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: He will not escape from darkness; a flame will dry up his shoots, and by the breath of his mouth he will go away.
verses.comment: Judgment imagery again dominates; darkness and fire also become images of final judgment in New Testament teachings.

verses.text: Let him not trust in emptiness, deceiving himself, for emptiness will be his reward.
verses.comment: Warning not to trust in vanity or self; this reflects the biblical call to authentic faith rather than mere words.

verses.text: It will be paid in full before his time, and his branch will not be green.
verses.comment: The theme of withering mirrors Jesus' teaching on the barren fig tree and spiritual fruitfulness (Mark 11:20-21; John 15:6).

verses.text: He will be like a vine that sheds its grapes too early, and like an olive tree casting off its blossom.
verses.comment: Fertility becomes a sign of divine favor; loss of fruit is judgment. Spiritually, fruitfulness is a mark of the soul's union with God (John 15:4-5).

verses.text: For the company of the godless will be barren, and fire will consume the tents of bribery.
verses.comment: Where there is evil, there is barrenness and destruction—fire being a common image of both purifying and destructive judgment in the Bible.

verses.text: They conceive trouble and give birth to evil, and their womb prepares deceit."
verses.comment: Evil is described in terms of conception and birth, showing the depth of sin in the human condition. This paves the way toward understanding the need for a Redeemer and corresponding new birth by the Spirit (see John 3:3-5).
